sen.j: 古袱紗（こぶくさ）とは、茶道の一部流派において、茶席での茶器の拝見や点て出しの際に用いられる小型の布である。
sen.e: A kobukusa is a small cloth used at some tea ceremony schools when they view tea bowls or when they carry out already whisked tea and present it to various other guests.

sen.j: 茶席において、点てられた抹茶を運ぶ際に茶碗の下に敷いたり、また流派・点前によっては茶器の拝見の際に畳の上に広げて同様に拝見する。
sen.e: This is placed under a tea bowl when the host of a tea ceremony carries a cup of whisked powdered green tea, and additionally, it is placed on a tatami mat to view a tea bowl at some tea ceremony schools or at some tea ceremony parties.

sen.e: After carrying a tea bowl, the host folds his or her kobukusa double and puts it into the inside of the front flap of kimono.

sen.j: 客側は、古袱紗のわさを左側に折り返し、新たにできた折り目の部分（わさ）を下側にして、懐紙・袱紗とともに懐中する。
sen.e: Guests fold their kobukusa ensuring the wasa (a seamless and folded side of a fukusa or a kobukusa) part should be folded over to the left, and turn the folded part (wasa) downward before putting it into the inside of the front flap of kimono with kaishi (Japanese tissue) and a fukusa (a small silk cloth used in the tea ceremony).

sen.j: 名物裂（めいぶつぎれ、めいぶつれつ織柄の決まった模様）や緞子（どんす）などが主に用いられるが、材質や色柄等は様々。
sen.e: Most kobukusa are made of meibutsugire (which literally means "named fabrics," representing cloths with certain woven patterns), which is also called meibutsuretsu, or donsu (damask silk), but various materials, colors, and patterns are used.

sen.j: 主に男性は寒色系や緑・紫など、女性は暖色系の色のものを使用するが、袱紗ほど厳密な決まりはなく、柄や色によっては男女で使い回すこともある。
sen.e: Although men's kobukusa generally use green and purple as well as other cold colors and women's kobukusa use warm colors, rules of kobukusa colors are less strict than fukusa; moreover, some kobukusa can be used by both men and women depending on colors and patterns.

sen.j: ウメ・桜・雪など季節を連想させる柄は、季節感を尊ぶ茶道においてはその時期以外はあまり好んで用いられることはない。
sen.e: Seasonal patterns such as plums, cherry blossoms, and snows are used only during their relevant seasons because the Japanese tea ceremony considers a sense of the season very important.

sen.e: However, some people allow cherry blossom patterns to be used all year round as cherry blossoms are thought to be the symbol of Japan.

sen.j: 大きさは袱紗の4分の1程度で、横幅が若干長いほぼ正方形の形をしている。
sen.e: The size of a kobukusa is one fourth of a fukusa, and its shape is almost a square although its width is a little wider.
